title: Why the WiseTech debate is not over
text:
Putting White’s aunty aside, no one has a greater reason to get the ship back on track than White, who owns 142 million shares in the business.

The value of that stake rose 6.2 per cent to just under $4 billion on Wednesday morning, recovering some of the ground lost since JCap launched its first attack last week, although the price of $27.94 seen on Wednesday morning was still some way off last Wednesday’s close of $34.40.

Clearly White’s confirmation of guidance – revenue in the 2020 financial year is tipped to grow between 26 per cent and 32 per cent, to between $440 million and $460 million, with earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation to grow between 34 per cent and 42 per cent to as high as $153 million – and of KPMG’s unqualified audit opinion have helped restore some confidence among investors.

Inherently complex

And beyond the inevitable he-said-she-said of WiseTech’s response to the research by JCap analyst Anne Stevenson-Yang, there is probably an argument to be made that White and his team have been able to knock the big claims of financial impropriety made by JCap on the head.

White should emerge from what he described on Wednesday as a “bump in the road” with exactly what the CEO of any listed company should welcome – a genuine, sensible and factual debate about business model and strategy.

It’s not just WiseTech’s sky-high valuation that will keep this debate going. It remains a mix of the complex and the simple.

The industry it works in is inherently complex, a global sector underpinned by a labyrinth of local laws and rules.

Advertisement

WiseTech’s key product, the CargoWise One freight-forwarding platform, is complex. White describes it as more Bloomberg than CommSec, due to the nature of the logistics sector.

And WiseTech’s business has an inherent level of complexity, having been built around 33 acquisitions, worth $400 million, over the last five years.

White made a strong case as to why WiseTech’s acquisition drive was actually less risky, cheaper and faster than trying to build out offices across a global network. Gaining the local knowledge, systems and processes required to operate inside a specific country’s logistics sector would have been impossible without making this long series of relatively small deals, he argues.

“There is no organics strategy – none – that would actually function in those circumstances,” White told investors.

Natural scepticism

“The entire business is deep and powerful and complex. If you want us to be an average business, we don’t do any of these things.”

White also argues the simple outputs of this complexity – high levels of recurring revenue, good organic growth, low customer attrition and strong profitability – show the model works.

But as White told Chanticleer, WiseTech is trying to do something that no one else has done in the logistics sector.

Advertisement

Pioneering strategies create competitive advantage, as WiseTech’s growth shows. But they also raise natural scepticism among investors.

Whether you agree with JCap’s approach or not – and White’s revelation that the firm didn’t ask WiseTech to clarify any issues before it launched its attack is not a point in JCap’s favour – it is reasonable that investors would look closely at the acquisition strategy on which the WiseTech empire was built.

Indeed, it was notable that White pointed to a slowdown in the pace of acquisitions in recent months, as the company beds down recent deals and refines its growth plans.

White’s final message for investors was pointed.

“Rest assured we are going to be running this business as hard as we were before JCap and after JCap.”
description: WiseTech's response to JCap should get it back to what all listed companies face: genuine, sensible and factual debate about business model and strategy.
